newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Naphtha/Mogas - Mogas recovers ahead of Taiwan.
newsitem.headline: Asia Naphtha/Mogas - Mogas recovers ahead of Taiwan.

text.p: Gasoline recovered slightly after Monday's slump, ahead of the closing of Taiwan's import tender, traders said on Tuesday.

Only buyers emerged, with a Japanese trader bidding up to $27.40 per barrel for 50,000 barrels of 95-octane unleaded lifting fob Singapore April 16-17. The grade traded on Monday at $27.00, losing more than a dollar from Thursday.
Unleaded 97-octane was bid at $28.30 for April 25-29.
Talk even emerged on the usually silent gasoline swaps market with April bid/offered at $27.20/$27.50.
"Because it's the closing date for CPC, people are bidding up the 95-octane so they can go in higher into Taiwan," one trader said.

Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp's (CPC) tender to buy its May 1-15 requirements - 250,000 barrels each of leaded and unleaded 95-octane reformate, closes Tuesday and is valid for two days.
CPC last bought through tender, 250,000 barrels of unleaded reformate at $28.60 per barrel, cost and-freight Taiwan for April 16-30 arrival.
Traders expected offers at least $1.00 per barrel over Singapore spot quotes, but said firmer indications will be heard on Wednesday.
Naphtha swaps eased by nearly 20 cents per barrel to $22.95/$23.10 for April and $22.60/$22.80 for May.
Traders assessed premiums notionally for Singapore May barrels in a wide range between 60 cents to $1.00 per barrel over Singapore spot quotes, fob, amid lack of firm talk.
MTH FOB SIN BUY/SELL PREV BUY/SELL
